valItem.desc: scratched with a knife or similar
crossed out with red or black ink, a line or dashes
marked with dots above or below the line, marked with lines above and below or encircled
deleted or washed out, the material is untouched
text written at the foot of the page
text written within the body of the text
text written to the left of the preceding text node
text written in the margin (left, right, or both)
text written both on top and left or right and bottom
text written on the opposite, i.e. facing, page
text written on the other side of the leaf
text written over previously deleted text
text written to the right of the preceding text node
text written at the top of the page
use this only when no information is currently available and make yourself a note to check photos or source to improve this point
The manuscript is badly preserved and severely damaged.
The manuscript is preserved with minimal damages.
The manuscript is preserved completely undamaged.
If you use this value, please provide in the description a proper motivation, otherwise avoid it.
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a msPart in a manuscript record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a person record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a place record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a msItem in a manuscript record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a handNote in a manuscript record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a item in the collation of a manuscript record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a manuscript record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a textual unit record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a repository record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a person record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a title in a textual unit record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a decoNote in the decoDesc of a manuscript record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a personGrp in a person record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of a bindingNote in the binding of a manuscript record
Please use this type if corresp is pointing to the xml:id of an authority file record
A record in the Studies repository
the work is contained completely in the manuscript
the work is contained incompletely in the manuscript, i.e. even only a small part is missing
syriaca.org: an existing print catalogue provides a descriptive title
syriaca.org: a title for such work established by the editor or cataloguer
for titleStmt, specifies to which title to give priority in output.
The title is a subtitle or title of a part
The title is an alternate title, translation, or alias
The title is a descriptive paraphrase of the work functioning as a title
The title is of a collection
Descriptions in manuscript catalogues of the subject of the record. This only makes sense if you are editing a manuscript record.
Editions of the Textual Unit (Work). This only makes sense if you are editing a Textual Unit.
Bibliography about the Textual Unit (Work), which is not an edition. This could also find its place in secondary bibliography.
About the same textual unit in a different literary tradition.
ID of the work in other clavis (CC, CPG etc.)
Secondary bibliography on the subject of the record.
Ruler of a country, region or similar
Occupation within an academic institution or independently pursuing academic interests
Christian Anglican, belonging to the Anglican Church after the reformation
Christian Catholic, belonging to the Catholic Church after 1054
Christian Protestant, belonging to a Protestant church after the reformation
Christian Orthodox, belonging to a pre-Chalcedonian Church or an Orthodox church after 1054
Christian Orthodox, belonging to the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church
Traditional non-Christian or Muslim belief system
the person who donated the manuscript
the person who donated the manuscript, typically to a library
the owner of a ms or an item
the commissioner of a ms or an item
the person paying for a ms (possibly not the same as donor/commissioner)
to be used only in person records, to idenfity a preferred option among the names provided.
the normalized transcription of the name in fidal or another script
name received later in life, different from the other specified types of names
name given on coronation (kings and queens but also patriarchs)
name given on entering monastic life
the name of the battle horse of kings and rulers
a name given to a person associated to his occupation or other deeds
nom de guerre (if different from horse name, e.g. Malas)
short form (diminutive or abbreviated, e.g. Taklo for Takla Māryām)
father's name, esp. for eventual Russian names, but could be also highlighted in others
the saint to whom the tābot is dedicated
manuscript format consisting of quires bound together to the spine, in their turn made up of a variable number of leaves sewn together and protected by two hard boards.
manuscript format consisting of one continuous flow of writing material rolled up, generally around one or two wooden cylindrical supports.
manuscript format consisting of one leaf assembled in a multiple zig-zag folding, resembling an accordion, and generally enclosed between two hard boards.
manuscript format consisting of one single unbound sheet.
An inscribed object different from a codex, scroll or leaf
An object consisting of an industrially produced paperblock in the form of a notebook.
A so called peacock-shaped parchment manuscript, folded as a fan.

a parchment membrane, or two or more such membranes, either sewn together edge-to-edge to form a continuous surface for writing, or laid together in a pile and sewn together at the head, and used by unrolling the membranes
a single sheet of parchment or paper, not intended to form part of a codex, either kept flat or folded (rather than rolled) for storage
a codex whose leaves are opened by unfolding rather than turning; an ‘almanac’
The format of the object is not known

@active: any record of the same type as @passive, @passive: any record of the same type as in @active. This special relation is used to mark that a deleted record (in @passive) is the same as the one in @active.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. Is the wife of ...
@active: Person, @passive: Person. Is the husband of..
@active: Person, @passive: Person. Is the mother of the legally conjugated partner.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. Is the father of the legally conjugated partner.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. Is the husband of the daughter.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. Is the wife of the son.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. The subject of the relation is the successor of...
@active: Person, @passive: Person. The subject of the relation is the predecessor of...
@active: Person, @passive: Person. Ordained priest, bishop or monk. Same as Consecrated.
@active: Person, @passive: Person. Has ordained to a religious ministry ...
@active: Person, @passive: Person. Has been baptized by ...

@active: Person, @passive: Work. The subject of the relation is author of a translation of a work in another language and there is no digital resource enabling us to document the authorship of this work and the fact that the work as such is a translation of another work.

@active: Place, @passive: Place. A related resource. Dublin Core relation Please use only if no other relation fits, and consider searching for a better option and suggesting that relation instead. This is now only suggested for those cases of unspecified relation between two places.
@active: Work, @passive: Manuscript. or @active: Person, @passive: Work. or @active: Place, @passive: Work. http://lawd.info/ontology/hasAttestation
Use for stratigraphic description. States that one or more identified discontinuities constitute a UniProd, which can be certain or hypothetical.
Use for stratigraphic description. States that a UniCirc or a UniProd contains the Units declared in the object passive.
Use for stratigraphic description. The Unit has one of the possible model for its class.
Use for stratigraphic description. Something happens to a UniCirc or less often a UniProd.
Use for stratigraphic description. Something happens to a UniCirc or less often a UniProd.
Use for stratigraphic description. If the model of the transformation is multiple, you can specify which individual parts constitute it.
Use for stratigraphic description. If the model of the transformation is simple, you can specify of which individual multiple transformation it is a part.
Use for stratigraphic description. A transformation produces new UniProds.
Use for stratigraphic description. A transformation results in a new UniProd or a new UniCirc.
Use for stratigraphic description. Certain or Hypothetique.
Use for stratigraphic description. Declares for a UniCirc one or more of the Stratum types in Andrist 2015, 512.
Use for stratigraphic description. Declares one or more of the Stratum types in Andrist 2015, 512 and assign them to a UniCirc.
Use for stratigraphic description. might be used to locate a unit defined relationally. If stated, a further relation is needed with one of the properties defining the locus.
Use for stratigraphic description. the locus range starts at.
Use for stratigraphic description. the locus range ends at.
Use for stratigraphic description. the locus has target.
Fine for everything, especially to match with external entities. http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exactMatch
Fine for everything, especially to match with external entities. http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#broadMatch
Fine for everything, especially to match with external entities. http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#closeMatch
Fine for every Authority File, especially to match with external SKOS vocabularies, e.g. Ligatus. Assumes this is a skos:Concept. http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#broader
Use for complex descriptions of Manuscripts or Works, passive should be an integer. http://erlangen-crm.org/efrbroo/CLP57_should_have_number_of_parts
Use for complex descriptions of Manuscripts or Works, passive should be an integer. http://erlangen-crm.org/current/P57_has_number_of_parts
Use for complex descriptions of Manuscripts or Works. http://erlangen-crm.org/efrbroo/CLP45_should_consist_of
Use for complex descriptions of Manuscripts or Works. http://erlangen-crm.org/efrbroo/CLP45i_should_be_incorporated_in
to contain apparatus criticus or textual notes
to contain bibliographical information, previous publications, etc.
to contain all editorial commentary, historical/prosopographical discussion, etc.
to contain the text of the edition itself; may include multiple text-parts
used to divide a div[type=edition] into multiple parts (fragments, columns, faces, etc.)
to contain a translation of the text into one or more modern languages
Restoration of text completely lost from the surface
Text erroneously omitted or skipped by the scribe
Editorial supplement of words subaudible to the native reader
Editorial explanation of oblique text in original
Text restored (e.g. from earlier witness or alternate copy) without specification of current state of this text
used to indicate a material loss or a portion of text that is to be hypothesized for material reasons ("it was there!"), but which is lost for loss of the material
a sign, pointing to the place where the text should be added
Words or lines skipped in omitted by the editor in transcription
Text omitted from the edition by the editor, for whatever reason (brevity, context, language, etc.)
The writing is above top line.
The writing is below top line.
The writing is variously above and below top line with no clear pattern.
Access to the item is restricted for conservation or other reasons.
The item is on exhibition at the owning library or another institution, and is likely to be temporarily unavailable.
The item is stored offsite, and will take at least twenty-four hours to produce.
Availability of the item is unknown.
